work.p: It is possible that these lines are early notes toward the second poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, a poem that would eventually be titled "A Song for Occupations." In this manuscript, Whitman writes of a worker being "not one whit less a man than the President." In the 1855 poem, Whitman asks, "Is it you then that thought yourself less? / It it you that thought the President greater than you? or the rich better off than you? or the educated wiser than you?" (1855, p. 58)

This manuscript also may relate to "Pictures," a lengthy manuscript poem held at the Beinecke Library at Yale University that was probably written in the mid- to late-1850s. The first several lines of the poem were published in 1880 as "My Picture-Gallery."

notesStmt.note: The handwriting and Whitman's use of the long "s" in several of the words suggest that this is an early manuscript. It is possible that these lines are early notes for the second poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, eventually titled "A Song for Occupations." This manuscript may also relate to "Pictures," a lengthy manuscript poem held at the Beinecke Library at Yale University that was probably written in the mid- to late-1850s.

bibl.title: "A Cluster of poems" and "Living Pictures"
bibl.orgName: Papers of Walt Whitman (MSS 3829), Clifton Waller Barrett Library of American Literature, Albert H. Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
On the back of this leaf is a list, almost certainly written later than the prose on the front, of subjects on which to write "a cluster of poems."

revisionDesc.change: unencoded long s, per kp request

div1.p: Evening, Nowhere, in the known world, can so many, and such beautiful living Pictures be seen as in these United States!

ab.seg: Here labourlabor is different from any other country in the world all forms of practical labourlabor is manly, recognized as honorable.—
The man who tends the President's horses, not one whit less a man than the President.—
The healthy, fine-formed girl who tends waits upon the great wealthy lady, not less than the wealthy Lady.—

div1.ab: He, who carries bricks & mortar to the mason, not less than the mason,
The mason who lays the bricks, not one tittle less than the builder, who engages employs, him,
The architect & builder of the house, no less than
